items.title: #F
items.description:
F Sharp (#F) is an open source cross-platform language, lead by Microsoft and part of the .NET languages. 

### Resources
* https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/F_Sharp_(programming_language)
* https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/articles/fsharp/tour
* http://www.tryfsharp.org/Create.

items.title: Rust
items.description:
Rust is an open source language, with Mozilla as lead contributor, focussed on concurrency and memory safety. 

### Resources
* https://www.rust-lang.org
* [arewewebyet](http://www.arewewebyet.org/).

items.title: Java
items.description: Java programming language has a long history. It is still widely deployed on webservers. Java is also the core language of Google's Android.

items.title: Objective-C
items.description:
Objective-C has a long past. It's still in the picture thanks to iOS having objective-c as the core language for its OS.

https://developer.apple.com/library/content/documentation/Cocoa/Conceptual/ProgrammingWithObjectiveC/Introduction/Introduction.html#//apple_ref/doc/uid/TP40011210

items.title: .NET
items.description:
.NET refers to several actual programming languages: C#, F# or Visual basic.

### Resources
* https://blogs.msdn.microsoft.com/dotnet/2017/02/01/the-net-language-strategy/
* https://www.microsoft.com/net

items.title: Go
items.description:
Go is open source software, with Google as lead contributor, with a focus on simplicity and reliability,

See https://golang.org/ or the [code playground](https://play.golang.org/).

items.title: Swift
items.description:
Developed for Apple's ecosystem (iOS, macOS). Swift is a modern language.

https://developer.apple.com/swift/

items.title: Ruby
items.description:
Ruby, made popular by the framework Ruby on Rails was adopted quickly for web development thanks to its simplicity and productivity. Compared to its sibling PHP, Ruby was seen a a breath of fresh air. Performance is still improving.

https://www.ruby-lang.org/en/

items.title: Python 3
items.description:
Python 3 is a highly anticipated successor to Python 2. But due to breaking changes, developers are relatively slowly migrating away from 2.0.

https://www.python.org

items.title: Python 2
items.description:
Python 2 is seen as a high quality language. It has a grand ecosystem and still under development, although its successor (v3) has been around for a while now.

https://www.python.org

items.title: PHP
items.description:
PHP has become popular as a easy to learn language and the default stack on web servers in the past decade. Challenged by many improved languages, PHP is still the backbone for much of the world's web development.

The latest, PHP7, is a still a reliable option for web development.

https://php.net/

states.label: Innovation trigger
states.description: A potential technology breakthrough kicks things off.

states.label: Peak expectation
states.description: Early publicity produces a number of success stories â€” often accompanied by scores of failures.

states.label: Disillusionment
states.description: Interest wanes as experiments and implementations fail to deliver. Producers of the technology shake out or fail.

states.label: Enlightenment
states.description: More instances of how the technology can benefit the market start to crystallize.

states.label: Productivity plateau
states.description: Mainstream adoption starts to take off. The technology's broad market applicability and relevance are clearly paying off.
